Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Linking Indigenous Knowledge and Science in Puget Sound: testing and refining Arctic models
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a small EAGER award to support the application and testing of models of traditional knowledge that have been developed in cooperation with Arctic communities and researchers by applying them to the Port Gamble S'Klallam Tribe. The Arctic has been at the forefront of defining and developing models based on the traditional knowledge of Arctic indigenous peoples. This research project will utilize research approaches developed in the Arctic for documenting arctic environmental change through indigenous knowledge and apply them to the Port Gamble S'Klallam case. PI Andrews notes that the insights gained in the Arctic are deeper than just observations of environmental change; they incorporate indigenous cultural perspectives of the natural environment as "social spaces" and incorporate the "personhood" of land and marine resources, thus engendering use and management responsibilities and guidelines. The Port Gamble S'Klallam Tribe's interest is in utilizing their traditional knowledge to inform long term decision making and management decisions about the environment and natural resources in the homelands of Puget Sound.

This project is a community participatory research project, the Port Gamble S'Klallam Tribe is collaborating with Andrews to explore how indigenous knowledge can inform a deeper understanding of the environmental change they are experiencing in their homelands, with the objective of informing both Tribal and State management practices. The PI will be working with the Port Graham S'Kallam Tribal elders and knowledgeable community members, as well as natural resource program staff to develop a model that can synthesize scientific and indigenous knowledge in order to develop an effective management and restoration program.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE NSF funding provided partial support for data collection, data organization, and initial data analysis through award 1059918, EAGER: Linking Indigenous Knowledge and Science in Puget Sound: testing and refining Arctic models. This community-based research project is the outcome of a collaborative partnership with the Port Gamble SÃ†Klallam Tribe, located in the upper Hood Canal region of Puget Sound/Salish Sea, Washington. The project addressed the need for understanding local experiences and cultural meanings associated with the environment that are incorporated in Indigenous Knowledge. Indigenous Knowledge generally is based on successfully living in and managing human impacts on local environments over long time periods--including adaptations to environmental change. As such, Indigenous Knowledge is being recognized as an essential component in developing sustainable and equitable responses to environmental challenges. Goal #1 was to assess the applicability of Arctic Indigenous Knowledge research methods to the Puget Sound socio-ecological system, which also is encountering major environmental threats to the health of its waters, and to the plants and animals (including humans) that have long depended on it for survival. Outcomes: Initial analysis indicates extant Arctic models for documenting Indigenous Knowledge are applicable to the Puget Sound socio-ecological system that shares some natural resource use practices and cultural connections, yet also includes important inter- and intra-regional variability. While global modeling of climate change is proving useful in many respects, resource conservation and restoration - including for the Port Gamble SÃ†Klallam Tribe and Indigenous Arctic communities- rely greatly on specialized, local knowledge. Goal #2 was to collect critical Indigenous Knowledge to synthesize with scientific data in developing effective tribal resource management and restoration programs. Outcomes: In-depth interviews with most tribal Elders and key community members provided a broader and longer information baseline than available through scientific studies. The project information will be used in designing Port Gamble SÃ†Klallam Tribe programs to restore and manage microhabitats that could support native species, and to provide test cases for reintroducing greater ecological diversity and resilience in Puget Sound. Interview digital recordings and transcripts are housed in the tribal archives and they record family histories of resource use and locations, current resource use areas and challenges, changes in resource availability and causes, recommendations for resource management and restoration efforts, major concerns, etc. These interviews successfully provided data needed by PGST staff in planning for future natural resource management and restoration projects. Goal #3 for this project focused on capacity building within several social dimensions. Outcomes: For the Port Gamble SÃ†Klallam Tribe, this project has contributed training for members addressing its research and resource management needs. As underrepresented minorities in resource management professions, it provided the opportunity for several tribal research assistants to build on their own backgrounds and the communityÃ†s indigenous knowledge in addressing increasing environmental issues locally, and to potentially contribute new perspectives for broader regional/national concerns.
